p: Four hypotheses have emerged to explain the possible role of antibodies in contributing to the control of Mtb infection and TB disease. The first hypothesis involves restricting the extent of initial Mtb infection in and around the alveolus by blocking Mtb physically, by inducing complement-mediated Mtb killing, and by stimulating enhanced phagocytic activity against Mtb. The second proposed mechanism involves balancing inflammation resulting from Mtb infection, mainly by redirecting pathologic innate immune activity in a way that reduces corresponding immunopathology. The third proposed mechanism involves regulation of granulomas, including prevention of granuloma formation (in light of the emerging theory that granulomas are used by Mtb to more efficiently spread infection via attraction of susceptible macrophages) and the clearance of Mtb-infected cells. Finally, antibodies may enhance dendritic cell and T-cell antigen presentation and regulation, through signals sent by specific Fc glycosylation patterns.
